intro: Hymenophyllum quadrifidum, commonly known as the four-veined moss, is a species of liverwort belonging to the family Porellaceae. It is characterized by its delicate, grass-like appearance and is typically found in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and rocky crevices. The plant has a thalloid structure with a distinct midrib and four lateral veins, giving it its common name. It reproduces via spores released from capsules that are borne on stalks called setae. Hymenophyllum quadrifidum plays a role in soil stabilization and provides habitat for various microorganisms in its ecological niche.
